title: Comfort Food
question_text:
While in college, Andrew ate chicken nuggets at least $5$ times per week. His average chicken nugget consumption in the colder months (October – March) was approximately symmetric with $\mu_c=20$ and $\sigma_c=2$. During the warmer months (April-September), his average chicken nugget consumption was approximately symmetric with $\mu_w=15$ and $\sigma_w=3$.
A random sample of $30$ meals from the cold months and $45$ meals from the warm months was analyzed. Let $\bar{x}_c-\bar{x}_w$ be the difference in the sample mean amount of chicken nuggets consumed during the cold and warm months.
What is the mean and standard deviation of the sampling distribution of the difference in average nuggets per meal in the cold and warm months for Andrew?
solution:
Solution

The sampling distribution of $\bar{x}_c-\bar{x}_w$ has mean $\mu_{\bar{x}_c-\bar{x}_w}=\mu_c-\mu_w=20-25=5$. The standard deviation is:

$$\sigma_{\bar{x}_c-\bar{x}_w}=\sqrt{\frac{\sigma^2_c}{n_c}+\frac{\sigma^2_w}{n_w}}=\sqrt{\frac{2^2}{30}+\frac{3^2}{45}}\approx0.577$$

Explanation of Distractors

Choice ‘B’ is incorrect.

The difference in the sample mean amount of nuggets consumed is computed correctly, however the variance is given in place of the standard deviation.

Choice ‘C’ is incorrect.

The difference in sample mean amount of nuggets consumed can be found by subtracting $\mu_w$ from $\mu_c$. The error is made by computing the average of sample means instead of the difference. Further error is made by computing the population variance without attention to sample size.

Choice ‘D’ is incorrect.

The difference in the sample mean amount of nuggets consumed is computed correctly, however the pooled variance is given in place of the standard deviation of the sampling distribution of difference in mean nugget consumption.

Choice ‘E’ is incorrect.

The difference in the sample mean amount of nuggets consumed is computed correctly, however the pooled standard deviation is given. Pooling is used in hypothesis testing when we are assuming that two populations are the same. In this instance, we know that the populations are not the same, and we are making generalizations about the sampling distributions thereof.
